webTitle: £2,000 fuel bills on the way, consumers warned

fields.bodyText: Householders have been warned that energy bills could rise by almost 50% over the next six years as EDF became the latest big six supplier to announce inflation-busting gas and electricity price increases. A new report from the government spending watchdog, the National Audit Office, also stokes the price row by claiming that ministers "do not know" whether power bills will be affordable in years to come, as multibillion pound infrastructure investment pushes up tariffs. The report says: "The available projections suggest that increases in both energy and water bills will continue to outstrip inflation, on average, up to 2030." The warning came as EDF unveiled plans to raise prices by 3.9% from January with a proviso – described as blackmail by critics – that the increase would be more if green taxes were not lifted by the government. EDF is building the £16bn Hinkley Point nuclear plant in Somerset, a government-underwritten project whose cost will eventually be passed to consumers. Vincent de Rivaz, chief executive of EDF in Britain, justified the rise and insisted his firm would be seen as a "force for good" for the UK in the long term. But the biggest shock on Tuesday came at the UK's annual energy industry conference, where Angela Knight, a former Tory MP and bank spokeswoman who is now chief executive for trade body Energy UK, revealed that new research from investment bank UBS predicted energy prices would rise by 46% in the years to 2020. This meant that prices have increased by 260% since 2004, according to UBS analysts who blamed a history of inadequate investment and social and environmental policies. UBS referred to an annual domestic bill of £1,100 but many consumers are already paying £1,500 which could mean a rise to well over £2,000 by 2020. Knight said energy companies had made some mistakes but were being unfairly blamed for much wider issues. "The industry has become a lightning conductor for the general concern about the cost of living. As a result we stand accused for things that we do, for things that we don't do, for things that we are responsible for and things that we are not … this is not an understood industry," she said. Knight argued that the UK still had the lowest gas price in the EU and among the lowest electricity costs. But she said the "old trilemma" of decarbonisation, energy security and affordability meant there was relentless upward pressure on prices. Guy Johnson, a director at RWE npower, a member of the big six, said he believed that energy security was more important than either affordability or decarbonisation. Ed Davey, the energy and climate change secretary, warned attendees at the conference that the latest round of bill rises "have not been fully and openly justified." However, the NAO has put further pressure on the government to intervene with a damning report saying there is little understanding in government of the financial implications of its own policies to bring much needed investment into energy, water and telecoms. The NAO recommends the Treasury should publish the expected overall impact on consumer bills, to promote transparency and debate about new infrastructure. It also argues departments should consider the implications for consumer bills and their overall affordability before making policy commitments on infrastructure. Amyas Morse, head of the National Audit Office, said: "Government and regulators do not know the overall impact of planned infrastructure on future consumer utility bills, or whether households, especially those on low incomes, will be able to afford to pay them. It seems critical to know 'how much is too much', based on reliable information." Davey also used the conference to renew his attack on Ed Miliband, describing the Labour leader's proposal to freeze energy prices as "intellectually bankrupt". The energy secretary said he remained convinced the government should not intervene in prices. "This will have a huge detrimental impact on the investment we need to deliver secure energy supplies. And an investment squeeze would mean a huge black hole in Britain's energy security – risking blackouts and higher prices in the long run," Davey said. Commenting on EDF's warning on green levies, the director of the Association for the Conservation of Energy, Andrew Warren, said: "It is absolutely disgraceful that a company that is majority owned by another government should be seeking to blackmail the UK government into changing its established policy to require energy companies to help customers stop wasting money by wasting fuel. "There has been no increase whatsoever in the levels of social obligations placed upon the big six this year. This concerted attack on the energy company obligation by the big six is predominantly a distraction technique to draw attention from the price gouging they are practicing." • This article was amended on Wednesday 13 November 2013 to insert a quote from the report.

webTitle: Why it matters who regulates Wall Street | Heidi Moore

fields.standfirst: Former Wall Street lawyer Timothy Massad is Obama's CFTC nominee. We'll find out whose side – Wall Street or the public – he's on soon
fields.body:
Today, President Obama is going to nominate a new head of a major financial regulatory agency. His job, unfortunately, will largely be to avoid making ripples and enforce new regulations that Wall Street lobbyists have written.

The president's nominee is Timothy Massad, a former Wall Street securities lawyer who joined the Treasury Department a few years back to help run the bank bailouts. He's an administration insider, and in his new position he's unlikely to be as controversial as the man he's replacing.

That man, Gary Gensler, has run what is America's smallest, and yet maybe its most important, agency to protect against future financial crises: the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, or CFTC.

The CFTC, under Gensler, has been a darling of the few remaining policymakers who listened to the complaints of Occupy Wall Street. The agency has been largely openly antagonistic towards Wall Street in the sense that it has insisted on more regulation of derivatives, the Jekyll-and-Hyde financial instruments that are as speculative as they are about reducing risk. The financial crisis showed us that derivatives, which are meant to help investors hedge against risk, are often abused as vehicles of profitable speculation. The question that is before Congress right now is: how do you allow derivatives while curbing the abuse?

Ken Griffin, the head of hedge fund Citadel, who has long worried about the dangers of derivatives, said at today's New York Times DealBook conference, "we've made progress".

The CFTC has made progress on 43 of the 60 rules it was assigned through the Dodd-Frank financial regulatory reform act – far more than any other regulatory agency. It has shot down ideas that had the potential to hurt smaller investors, like the short-lived proposal to allow people to bet on opening weekends of Hollywood movies.

Gensler, a former Wall Streeter himself, revealed in a recent speech how he did it. In essence, in a world where almost everyone Congress spoke to was a lobbyist against financial regulation, he decided to be a lobbyist for financial regulation. As he said recently:

Our tactics included giving speeches, providing Congress with legislative and technical assistance, placing opinion pieces in leading newspapers and actively working with coalitions of supporters outside of Congress.

He also made the CFTC more technologically savvy than its brethren at the Securities and Exchange Commission.

But the trend for the CFTC, as it stands right now, is not a promising one. The agency is funded with only $195m, a pittance in the context of the $700tn industry it regulates. Running on so little cash, the CFTC has had to put aside some investigations and run on a kind of life support.

There's also the fact that the success of Gensler and his former enforcement chief, David Meister, have earned Wall Street's ire and strengthened the financial industry's determination to fight them.

As a result, Gensler's team has lost some significant battles, including, notably, the one in which Citigroup lobbyists managed to write 70 out of 85 lines of a recent regulatory bill.

Big blowups of commodities firms like MF Global and Peregrine Financial, who wiped out farmers and investors as they went under, also made investors wonder if the CFTC was minding the store as well as it could. The CFTC responded by implementing new safeguards to protect customers' money – as yet untested.

But the CFTC's big upcoming challenge will be to hold its position on regulation. The big regulatory fights over the next year or two – as Wall Street continues to hammer away at Dodd-Frank – will concern the most complicated parts of the financial system. Derivatives are one part of that. Another part is the benighted, bloated Volcker Rule, which is designed to prevent banks from speculating with the money of depositors.

Wall Street, with its superior financing power and infinite patience, used to wearing Washington down by pouring coin, is going to keep these fights backstage, as befitting what Griffin called the industry's "cartel mentality". It's going to be ugly, and it's going to be quiet.

This is the situation Massad is inheriting. Gensler, an 18-year veteran of Goldman Sachs with a history of opposing derivatives regulation, came to his job with the zeal of the converted and was wise to many of Wall Street's tricks. Wall Street firms supported his nomination initially because they thought he was theirs, a made man. He became a surprising thorn in the side of the financial industry during his tenure at the CFTC.

As a result, Massad will likely be under pressure to "play nice" and create less friction than Gensler did. We'll find out during his Congressional testimony whether that is his intent. But it would be a shame if it is.

webTitle: Pets at Home eyes flotation next year

fields.standfirst: IPO expected in the first quarter of 2014 would value Britain's biggest pet retailer at well over £1bn
fields.body:
Pets at Home is hoping to cash in on signs of a rise in Keynes' "animal spirits" among investors by floating on the stock market early next year.

A flotation would see Pets at Home join a procession of major UK companies that have listed in London recently. The initial public offering, expected in the first quarter of 2014, would value Britain's biggest pet retailer at well over £1bn.

Pets at Home's owner, private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts (KKR), has instructed Goldman Sachs, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, Nomura and its own team to work on the IPO.

Royal Mail's successful privatisation last month added impetus to the previously stagnant market for IPOs. Other recent offerings include Merlin Entertainments, which owns Madame Tussauds, and estate agent Foxtons.

KKR bought Pets at Home four years ago for £955m. The pet supplies chain has 360 stores and a string of veterinary surgeries.

The chain's management recently set out a new three-year plan after posting rising annual sales and profits in August. Nick Wood, its chief executive, said he wanted to add new stores and trading formats despite caution over customers' squeezed incomes.

The company declined to comment on the IPO plans, which are said to be at an early stage.

webTitle: Vodafone's post-Verizon push in Europe is a slow burner

fields.bodyText: Vodafone has launched chapter three of its corporate life – the post-Verizon Wireless years – with a blizzard of jargon: it will "leverage group synergies" and "turbo-charge differentiation". If that sounds vague, the bill is not. Under Project Spring, the extra sums being applied to improve Vodafone's network around the world, especially in Europe, will amount to £7bn; and the investment will be made over two years, not three as previously advertised. This is extra spending on top of the £6bn or so Vodafone would invest annually anyway. It can be done because Vodafone's balance sheet will be transformed by the $130bn (£84bn) sale of its 45% stake in Verizon Wireless, even after $84bn (£54bn) has been dispatched to shareholders. Is that a post-disposal knees-up or sensible investment? There's a fair case for the latter since, in a world of converging and improving technologies, companies with big chequebooks ought to be able to gain a competitive edge. Besides, Vodafone has to try to arrest its weak revenues in Europe and fight the cable intruders. The half-year numbers showed an "organic" decline in group revenues of 3.2%, with northern Europe (down 3.9%) and southern Europe (off 14.9%) being the major drags. If Vodafone is correct in thinking the European market stands on the brink of better times, now is as good a time as any to press the accelerator. And, thankfully, the 3G and 4G targets for the extra dosh are detailed more precisely than the jargon suggests. It's just that a seven-year payback on a £7bn spending programme is hardly electrifying. In the circumstances, you can't blame some of Vodafone's shareholders for hoping AT&T will turn up with a bid. The revelation that Vodafone has deferred tax assets of £18bn may encourage the thought. But if the AT&T tale goes quiet, chapter three for Vodafone looks like it could be a long and expensive slog.

webTitle: Vodafone eyes entry into UK pay-TV

fields.bodyText: Vodafone plans to wade into the UK pay-TV business, in a move that would further shake an industry reeling from BT's £900m swoop for the rights to Champions League football. The plan is high on the agenda, group chief executive Vittorio Colao said at the company's half-year financial results on Tuesday. "We will offer unified, converged, multiscreen services in all countries. What that will look like in Britain I don't know yet," Colao said. "We have a new chief executive of the UK starting and they will help develop the strategy … I will be doing a lot of thinking in the next few months about the impact of telecoms companies owning content." Vodafone has earmarked £19bn to upgrade its networks over the next two years, £7bn of which will come from the sale of its US business, Verizon. Promising "perfect voice" services with 50% fewer dropped calls and the best 4G mobile internet services in Europe, Vodafone said it will invest £1.2bn in the UK, including £300m of Verizon cash. Its efforts will be focused on London, with £150m spent improving coverage in the capital. "We really can make a difference in a way that our competitors cannot catch up on," said its finance director, Andy Halford. "We want to create some blue sky between us and the rest." Verizon cash is also being used for a bumper shareholder payout and to reduce debt. Vodafone will use its stronger balance sheet to fund more acquisitions. Some of those are expected to be in the pay-TV arena. The announcement that Vodafone is considering offering what marketers call quad play – TV, landline, broadband and mobile services – in its home country marks a change in stance. The group had previously said it would avoid Britain's overcrowded subscription TV arena; TalkTalk, BT, Virgin Media and Sky are competing alongside internet film and TV subscription services such as Netflix and Apple's iTunes. Vodafone will not rush into an expansion of its British business, but Jeroen Hoencamp, who stepped up to run Vodafone's UK business on Monday, has the task of devising the strategy. This could involve acquiring another company or going into partnership with one. Colao said Vodafone had discussions with Liberty Global, which bought Virgin Media earlier this year, about sharing content and networks, although the talks did not result in a deal. Last month, Virgin extended its contract with EE, whose masts it uses for its Virgin Mobile virtual network. In Europe, where many former national telecoms companies held on to their mobile phone businesses, Vodafone is under pressure because wireless services are sold at knockdown prices to attract customers to fixed-line broadband. Orange owns the French national broadband network and a string of mobile businesses throughout Europe. In Germany, where T-Mobile is owned by Deutsche Telekom, Vodafone has moved into TV by acquiring cable company Kabel Deutschland. Britain differs because BT spun off its Cellnet mobile business as a separately listed entity which eventually became O2. However, fresh from the launch of its sports channels, BT is planning its virtual mobile network in partnership with EE next year. Investors are speculating that, despite plans to turn itself into a multimedia group, Vodafone could ultimately be sold off. America's AT&T, which has no assets in Europe, is thought to be weighing up a bid for Vodafone or EE in Britain. "There is every reason for AT&T, or other candidates, to be interested," said Robin Bienenstock, an analyst at Bernstein Research. "Speculation on Vodafone as a potential acquisition target will continue to support the stock.". Vodafone is hoping to spend its way into a leading position to take full advantage of the predicted European recovery. However, its revenues are under pressure. Financial results for the six months to 30 September show service revenue – which includes calls, texts and data charges but excludes handsets – was down nearly 5% across the group, with southern Europe falling nearly 16%. "We are seeing this as an opportunity to over-invest to prepare for economic recovery," said Colao. The moves Vodafone might make Sign a Partnership Vodafone could secure a network-sharing deal with BT or Virgin Media, leasing broadband lines in exchange for sharing its mobile network. But both companies have recently committed to EE. Acquire Liberty Global Liberty bought Virgin Media earlier this year and its shares rose sharply in August on speculation Vodafone might buy the European cable TV group. Acquire BSkyB Rupert Murdoch's satellite company is not up for sale but if BT were to win the lion's share of Premier League rights in 2015 it might be. Acquire TalkTalk The budget pay-TV operator has a growing tribe of 4 million customers and would be a smaller mouthful to swallow than Sky, but it does not own a fibre network. Sell to AT&T The Texan telecoms behemoth is looking for trophy European assets and is thought to have Vodafone on its shopping list. • This article was amended on 13 November 2013. "There is every reason for AT&T, or other candidates, to be interested," said Robin Bienenstock, an analyst at Bernstein Research. "Speculation on Vodafone as a potential acquisition target will continue to support the stock.".

Acquire BSkyB Rupert Murdoch's satellite company is not up for sale but if BT were to win the lion's share of Premier League rights in 2015 it might be.

webTitle: American Airlines-US Airways $11bn merger given preliminary blessing

fields.standfirst: Justice Department gives blessing in court document, though US authorities had previously moved to block the merger
fields.body:
The US Justice Department has given a preliminary blessing to American Airlines' proposed merger with US Airways, according to a court document filed on Tuesday.

US authorities had moved to block the merger, which would create the world’s largest airline, arguing it would harm consumers by increasing fares and reducing competition.

Under the proposal American and US Airways would sell 104 takeoff and landing slots at Reagan national airport in Washington, 34 slots at La Guardia Airport in New York and assets at five other airports, including Boston, Chicago and Los Angeles.

"This agreement has the potential to shift the landscape of the airline industry. By guaranteeing a bigger foothold for low-cost carriers at key US airports, this settlement ensures airline passengers will see more competition on non-stop and connecting routes throughout the country," said attorney general Eric Holder.

The settlement still needs to be approved by the Federal District Court in the District of Columbia but will halt a trial scheduled for later this month.

The $11bn merged entity would have a fleet of 1,500 aircraft, $39bn in revenues and would employ 100,000 people. If it goes through, it will be the third major US airline merger since 2008, a trend that has fueled fears of higher ticket prices and fewer choices for consumers.

On Monday, Virgin America raised fresh objections to the merger and asked to file an amicus curiae (friend of the court) brief to argue against allowing the merger to go forward even if the merged company was forced to give up slots at key airports.

“Virgin America believes that it can show the Court that unless this merger is blocked, a simple fix for a few large airports will leave most of the hub-hub routes as monopoly markets and the connecting city pairs and all the passengers who travel in them without any remedy at all,” Virgin America said in its filing with the US district court in Washington, DC.

The Justice Department had not challenged an airline merger since 2000's proposed United-US Airways merger. Since then, United and Continental have merged, as have Delta and Northwest.

When the merger was announced in February nonprofit group American Antitrust Institute (AAI) called for an investigation, arguing the deal would substantially reduce competition, create regional strongholds at key airports and deprive smaller communities of air service.

In a study published with the Business Travel Coalition the AAI said ticket prices had risen 20% on some key Delta routes and 30% on several United-Continental routes after their mergers.

AMR, American Airlines’ parent company, filed for bankruptcy in 2011. It won approval to exit bankruptcy protection in September.

webTitle: Pay day lender Wonga reshuffles management

fields.standfirst: Co-founder and CEO Errol Damelin is moving to a part-time chairman role while co-founder Jonty Hurwitz is leaving
fields.body:
Controversial pay day lender Wonga has shuffled its management to allow its co-founder and highest profile executive Errol Damelin to move to a part-time role.

The other co-founder of the business Jonty Hurwitz – who is also an artist – is leaving the company. Wonga, which quotes APRs of 5,853%, has incurred the wrath of the archbishop of Canterbury, who wants to set up credit unions to compete it out of existence.

Damelin and Hurwitz founded Wonga in 2008 with backing from a number of private equity firms. South Africa-born Damelin is moving from chief executive to part-time chairman, replacing Robin Klein, who provided seed capital for Wonga and has been in the chairman's seat for seven years.

"These changes will free up my time to focus on where Wonga should be heading in the next decade, as we continue to develop as an international digital finance business," said Damelin.

The company insisted the changes were not a precursor to a stock market flotation but reflected the changes underway at Wonga. In October it bought the German payment firm BillPay, adding to deals in Spain, where it bought Credito Pocket. It also owns a stake in Nahar Credits Private.

Niall Wass, hired from Betfair in 2012 to become chief operating officer, will become chief executive. According to his LinkedIn profile, Wass is based in Geneva, where Wonga has an address. He recently conducted a number of TV interviews to hit back against the idea that Wonga's customers were poor and vulnerable.

In one with ITV News at 10 he challenged the Archbishop of Canterbury to use Wonga. "What I am asking him and others to do – go use the service, see if you think it is fair and transparent. Take out £30 for 10 days, pay it back after a week and then judge us by our customers," he said.

Wonga has recently launched a feature film, entitled 12 Portraits, to try to bolster its public image by telling real stories about its customers.

webTitle: Aberdeen Asset falls on bidding war fears while FTSE treads water

fields.standfirst: Mining shares prove a drag on the market as investors await UK jobs figures
fields.body:
Aberdeen Asset Management led the market lower on growing fears it could be caught up in a bidding war for Scottish Widows Investment Partnership.

The business is being sold by Lloyds Banking Group, and Aberdeen was believed to be the frontrunner with an offer of around £500m. But Australia's Macquarie is expected to enter the fray with its own bid, and Aberdeen investors are concerned an auction could develop.

Aberdeen's shares fell 19.7p to 416.9p, making it the biggest faller in an uncertain FTSE 100.

Better than expected UK inflation figures, making an interest rate rise less likely, did little to enthuse the market, with Wednesday's unemployment numbers and inflation report perhaps painting a different picture.

Overall the FTSE 100 finished 1.58 points lower at 6726.79, not helped by a fall in metal prices and mining shares, on worries about the US Federal Reserve beginning to cut back its $85bn a month bond buying programme. Investors took little comfort from the latest 10 year economic plan from China, a key consumer of commodities. The country's authorities called for far reaching economic and tax reforms, improving budget management and balance spending and revenues. Nikolaus Keis at UniCredit said there were no major surprises, but implementation was key.

Brenda Kelly, senior market strategist at IG, said:

Investor risk appetite was the missing ingredient today for European indices, which manifested itself in declines for the mining and financial sectors. Richard Fisher, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, urged markets to prepare for a stimulus reduction, sparking the usual tapering fears. However, the small losses registered this afternoon do not imply any near-term panic.
China's Third Plenum, a private conclave held by Chinese officials aiming to implement key reforms in the country, kept the markets guessing and capped gains in the commodity suite. The capping effect on the country's mining sector – comprising a key constituent of the FTSE – has kept the UK tied to a tight 20-point range, unable to make any real gains through 6720.

So Fresnillo fell 37p to 915.5p while Anglo American was 33.5p lower at 1440.5p. Randgold Resources dropped 77p to £46.11 after RBC analysts moved from outperform to sector perform.

GlaxoSmithKline lost 13p to 1637.5p after a disappointing trial result for an experimental heart drug. Darpladib failed to reduce the risk of heart attacks and strokes in the first of two Phase 3 clinical studies. Not many analysts had expected significant sales from the product but the result still disappointed the market.

Royal Bank of Scotland slid 8.2p to 331.6p after analysts at Nomura repeated their reduce recommendation, albeit edging up their price target from 270p to 285p, and Goldman cut its rating from buy to neutral.

Nomura said investors needed to be patient to see a recovery at RBS - which has set up an internal good and bad bank - and there was potential for disappointment.

These new recommendations came just a day after analysts at Jefferies raised their price target on RBS from 390p to 441p, so it is safe to say there is a wide range of views on the bank in the City.

Among the risers, Irish building materials group CRH climbed 50p to £16.09 as it kept its guidance for the year and said it would review its businesses to identify further disposals.

BSkyB recovered 11p to 840p, or just over 1%, after Monday's 10% slump in the wake of the satellite broadcaster losing out to BT for the next Champions League rights.

RSA Insurance, hit by problems in its Irish business, also rose 1.3p to 109.4p after its recent slump.

Vodafone added 3.9p to 231.25p as it said it planned to invest £7bn in its network after service revenues fell 4.9% in the second quarter, due to weak trading in Europe.

Meanwhile the Norwegians seem to like Tesco, even if US investment guru Warren Buffett has gone off the UK supermarket. Norges Bank has bought 11m shares to take its stake to 492m or 6.09% of Tesco, down 1.2p at 366.8p. Last month Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway business cut its stake in Tesco by around a fifth to 3.98%.

Lower down the market, John Menzies dropped 52.5p to 767p after it said poor trading in its distribution business would lead to lower than expected full year profits.

Also heading lower was Balfour Beatty, which fell 9p to 274.5p after UBS cut from neutral to sell.

But TalkTalk Telecom pleased the market with its results, adding 25.5p to 275.4p after first half revenues rose 1.8% to £843m and it forecast a 3% rise for the full year. It signed up 167,000 TV customers in the three months to September, putting it on track for a million viewers.

BTG was 30.6p better at 454.9p as the healthcare group reported an 18% rise in first half profits to £32.7m and gave a positive outlook for the year.

Sportech, the football pools and tote betting company, slipped 1p to 86.5p, as it issued an line trading update. It revealed that an appeal by HMRC against the award of £95m to the company in respect of a VAT claim would be heard next April. The company said:

The group continues to explore options available to secure financial benefit in the event of the favourable decision of [the original tribunal decision] being ultimately reversed.

Nick Batram at Peel Hunt said:

Today's statement contains little in the way of new news but it does reiterate the building momentum in Racing. Investment in Connecticut venues should see the new $2.4m sports bar open on time (in December) at Windsor Locks, while the handle at the recent Breeders' Cup meeting in California was up 10% year on year. Meanwhile, the new B2C online wagering platform will go fully live in December in Connecticut. One piece of new news is confirmation that HMRC's VAT appeal is scheduled to be heard by the Upper Tribunal on 29 and 30 April next year.
We [recently] highlighted a number of catalysts that could materially boost the bottom line. These range from extended gaming legislation in Connecticut to expansion of Californian betting venues to the VAT claim. The upside from here on our base case is around 30% or 145% on a bull case, yet the downside is just 12%. Buy.

Oxford Instruments jumped 16% to £14.25 after the industrial group issued an upbeat trading statement and unveiled a £160m bid for Belfast-based Andor Technology.

It is offering 500p a share for Andor, which specialises in scientific digital cameras, but the move was greeted coolly. Andor said it first received an indicative cash offer on 9 July, and this was since raised by 19% to 500p, with talks continuing. Andor, which added 22% to 490p, said:

The board is disappointed that, having only made the indicative proposal on 8 November, Oxford Instruments has chosen to make today's announcement which the board considers to be premature and unhelpful in light of ongoing discussions.
Given the level of uncertainty and conditionality, the board felt it could not properly consider the proposal, but it did confirm to Oxford that it remained willing to continue discussions.

Andor shareholder SVG Investment Managers advised rejecting the bid, saying it expected overseas interest in the business.

Finally Rightster, which specialises in online video rights management and counts ITN, the British Fashion Council and the Guardian among its clients, made a bright start to life as a public company. It raised £20.4m with a placing of shares at 60p, valuing the business at £70m. The shares closed at 72p.

webTitle: UK inflation rate hits 13-month low of 2.2% - as it happened

fields.standfirst:
• UK inflation - live coverage starts here
• Labour: Cost of living crisis continues
• Treasury: hard work is paying off
• Graph: inflation over the last decade
fields.body:
5.25pm GMT

Coming up on Wednesday...

It is a busy day for economic data in the UK on Wednesday. Here is a quick look at what lies ahead:

At 9.30am, Office for National Statistics data on the labour market is expected to show the unemployment rate held at 7.7% in in July to September while average earnings growth edged up to 0.9% from 0.8%, according to a Reuters poll of economists. As mentioned before, the Bank of England has given a 7% unemployment threshold before which it will not consider hiking interest rates - barring various "knockouts" being triggered.

At 10.30am, the Bank of England publishes its quarterly inflation report. More on that from earlier today.

They will no doubt be more news on the effects of state-backed housing market schemes Funding for Lending and Help to Buy in a trading statement out early from housebuilder Barratt Developments. The strength of consumer spending as retailers head into the key Christmas season will be under the spotlight when J Sainsbury, the supermarket, publishes half-year results.

Eurozone industrial production is out at 10.00am UK time and Spain is the latest country to release inflation data at 8.00am.

Before we go, a quick round-up of where things stand on stock markets:

The FTSE 100 closed down just 1.6 points at 6,726.8. Germany's Dax is down 0.3% to 9,076.5 and in France the CAC40 is off 0.6% at 4,263.8.

In the US, the S&P 500 is down 0.3% at 1,767, the Dow Jones industrial average is off 0.3% at 15,729 and the Nasdaq is down 0.3% at 3,908.

With that I am signing off for today. We will be back in the morning with rolling coverage of business and economic news. Thanks for reading and for all the comments.

4.49pm GMT

The risks of the Czech currency experiment

While the UK government welcomes a slowdown in inflation today, in the Czech Republic, central bankers have been worrying about deflation. After the Czech national bank's move last week to weaken the country's crown currency, Stephen Lewis, chief economist at Monument Securities has been considering whether it is right to think - as US Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke claimed in November 2002 - that a central bank always could and always should use every device it could imagine to prevent a situation where prices fall, conventionally labelled 'deflation'.

Lewis was prompted to consider this, he says, after the Czech central bank (CNB) launched crown sales on the open market for the first time in over a decade last Thursday, to weaken the currency and help stem a slowdown in inflation. Reuters has the deails here. And thanks to business live reader londondavid for highlighting the move on the day.

Lewis warns the central bank's policy risks pushing the Czech economy back into recession. "To court that danger simply because US economists of Mr Bernanke's stamp have theoretical notions on how the economy works shows how central bankers are still in awe of old thinking," he says.

He comments:

CNB policymakers, or at least a majority of them, appear to have judged they could wait no longer in forestalling deflation risks and so decided to implement their fx plan.

Deliberately devaluing one's currency is, of course, frowned upon in international circles. Japan has already established a precedent that exchange rate depreciation is fine with the global community if it happens to occur as an unintended consequence of domestic monetary actions. The CNB could hardly find comfort in that, however, since its policy is treating the exchange rate as a target and has involved active intervention on the exchanges to achieve its goal. There is a closer parallel with Switzerland, though the Swiss franc had been appreciating rapidly against the currency of its major trading partner, the euro zone, when the Swiss National Bank decided in September 2011 to cap its rate against the euro at 1.20. The Czech koruna, by contrast, had been fairly stable against the euro for months prior to the CNB's decision. Further, there had been brighter news on the Czech economy, in confidence indices and PMI data, raising doubts in some quarters whether a yet more accommodative monetary policy was needed at all.
The CNB justified its policy of fx sales in terms of preventing long-term undershooting of its inflation target. Mr Tomsik, a CNB vice governor, expressed the thinking behind the CNB's move in revealing terms. 'We would be in deflation for a very long period, easily three quarters if not longer, because economic theory shows that it is difficult to crawl out of deflation once you get stuck in it.' It is worth noting that this central banker regards nine months as a 'very long time'. It seems that, for him and his fellow-thinkers, even one month when the consumer price index is lower than in the corresponding month of the previous year is reason for deep concern.

Then, there is his appeal to 'economic theory'. To be sure, some textbooks lay it down as indubitable truth that deflation is hard to escape and, as they understand the deflation process, they may be right. But that is not to say that any period when prices happen to fall is to be labelled 'deflationary'. There has, perhaps, been too much focus on Japan's experience, without regard for the special influences affecting that country, in assessing the proper priorities of monetary policy. After all, the USA recorded eight successive months of negative annual CPI inflation in 2009 without identifiable harm.

Mr Janacek, a more robust member of the CNB's board, declared prior to last week's policy meeting that he would rather tolerate a few months of moderate 'deflation' than risk shocking the economy with a radical fx policy. We may well suppose the most immediate effect of the fx depreciation will be a rise in Czech import prices and a squeeze on Czech domestic purchasers' spending power. Though consumer prices may not now fall, the CNB's policy risks pushing the Czech economy back into recession. To court that danger simply because US economists of Mr Bernanke's stamp have theoretical notions on how the economy works shows how central bankers are still in awe of old thinking. We shall be watching the Czech experiment closely for the broader implications it might have for monetary management in the advanced economies.

Updated at 4.52pm GMT

3.44pm GMT

UK fuel poverty rises and wage growth slows

After this morning's news of a significant slowdown in UK inflation there were plenty of commentators quick off the mark in noting that at 2.2%, it is still three times the average pace of wage growth. Now comes a separate report suggesting wage growth fell in recent months and another claiming fuel poverty is up.

Data from VocaLink, the company that processes the large number of payments for UK workers, underlines the pressure on earnings. It says that despite recent signs of improvement in the UK economy its latest Take Home Pay Index shows that wage growth has slowed.

The monthly index shows that pay growth in FTSE 350 companies fell to 2.2% in the three months to the end of October from 2.4% in the three month to end September.

Looking at pay sector by sector, it says:

  • Services sector take home pay growth slowed slightly year-on-year in the three months to October – down to 2.5% from 2.7% in the three months to September
  • Annual take home pay in the manufacturing sector fell by 0.7% in the three months to October, following several months of slowing growth
  • However the public sector experienced annual take home pay growth at 0.1% for the first time since March 2013.

David Yates, VocaLink's chief executive:

This month’s Take Home Pay Index highlights that across multiple sectors wage growth remains sluggish. While inflation has remained steady for over a year, rising prices of essentials are putting pressure on households and recent increases in domestic gas and electricity bills mean household spending continues to be squeezed.

With the pace of wage growth slowing, there may be concerns about the prospect of consumer spending worsening as retailers head toward the crucial Christmas sales period.

A separate report from Legal & General suggests 1 in 3 households say they will be in fuel poverty this winter, up 53% on the same period last year. That is based on the government’s definition of paying 10% of income on gas and electricity.

Its MoneyMood Survey adds:

The number of homes across the UK who say they are “In fuel poverty now or will be in the next three months” is 6.8 million, up 2.4 million on the equivalent figure for 2012 (4.4 million). This is significantly higher than the latest Government estimates of 3.2 million homes in fuel poverty, which is based on 2011 data.

In many regions the number of households in fuel poverty is even higher.

Two regions have almost 1 in 2 in fuel poverty – in the East Midlands 48% say they are in fuel poverty (up 152%). Similarly in the North East 48% of homes are in fuel poverty (up 140%).

3.22pm GMT

Greek repossessions in troika's sights

Over in Greece, word is coming through that ahead of this afternoon's meeting, visiting troika inspectors have been focusing on lifting the blanket ban on repossessions of properties in a bid to rejuvenate the market and as our correspondent in Athens, Helena Smith, says it is a potentially explosive issue.

She writes:

No subject is quite as neuralgic as that of doing away with the blanket ban on repossessions of properties whose owners owe less than 200,000 euro. In a sign of the mounting tension around the issue, visiting troika inspectors insisted that the prohibition, which is to be in force until 31 December, was the focus of today's talks at the finance ministry.

Indicatively, the talks were attended by the heads of Greek banks, the development minister Kostis Hadzidakis, the Justice minister Charalmbos Athanasiou and the finance minister Yannis Stournaras, all of whom are under immense pressure to lift the ban when it effectively ends at the end of the year. The vast majority of non-performing loans are believed to derive from mortgage payers defaulting on their debt with bankers classifying around 30% of borrowers as "strategic defaulters" who can pay but chose not to pay because of other debts they deem more expedient.

The ban, passed by a previous socialist government, has in the main been blamed by bankers for the defaults. With lack of liquidity an ever more pressing issue in a market that became lifeless long ago, the troika is pressuring the government to allow banks to auction off homes in the hope it will rejuvenate the Greek property market - one of the first victims of the country's debt crisis.

A development ministry official conceded that although the fragile coalition sees the issue as "another red line" - with at least ten MPs resolutely refusing to endorse such a measure in parliament -- the heat was now on for the government to "make a decision by December 15."

"What we are trying to do is protect the poor, vulnerable groups who absolutely cannot lose their home," he said. "There is enormous pressure for the issue to be settled by the middle of next month."

According to Greece's central bank, first-home owners account for the majority of 100,000 plus mortgages in arrears with officials reporting a leap in numbers in recent months because of a three-year backlog in annual property taxes that property owners have had to pay as part of government efforts to boost revenue.

Without a compromise analysts believe prime minister Antonis Samaras' increasingly frail coalition could fall. MPs have said repeatedly they will not allow foreclosures to pass with one saying publicly it will tip the country into civil war.

Larry Elliott on inflation and the spending squeeze

Our economics editor, Larry Elliott, has been looking at the UK's inflation numbers and says the drop in the rate to 2.2% suggests the cost of living is finally responding to a lack of spending power.

He writes:

Inflation is in retreat across the west. Although the City of London was focusing on the unexpectedly sharp fall in the UK's cost of living, this was merely part of a general trend from Hungary to Portugal and from Italy to Germany. Deflation is already a reality for some of the troubled countries on the fringes of the eurozone area. Others are heading in that direction.

For now, that list does not include Britain where the current inflation rate of 2.2% is still (just) above the government target and higher than the eurozone average, which is already 0.7% and likely to fall lower when new figures are out later this week.

But the data from the Office for National Statistics is still significant in three material respects. First, it suggests that the cost of living is finally responding to a lack of spending power...

The second point to note - as Labour did - is that the gap between price increases and wage increases remains even after the fall in inflation from 2.7% to 2.2%, because average earnings are growing by less than 1% a year...

Finally, falling inflation provides a breathing space for the Bank of England. As Capital Economics notes, the economy is currently in a sweet spot in which price pressures are abating even though the economy is growing at an annual rate of around 3% a year.

'Key 24 hours for the pound'

Newly arrived Bank of England governor Mark Carney's forward guidance introduced in August uses a threshold of 7% unemployment, before which poliycmakers say they will not consider raising interest rates (barring various knockouts being triggered - lots more detail on that from the Bank here). If it does so, it will go to great lengths to reiterate that it will only use that as an occasion to reassess the state of the economy. Especially, if it does not make material increases to the inflation forecasts, it will feel able to resist the pressure for early rate increases.

Note also recent developments in other markets. The ECB has just cut rates as it is fearful of inflation falling far below target. That indicates a downside growth risk in the euro area, the UK’s largest export market. The Bank will reiterate what that risk means for the UK.
