The strength of consumer spending as retailers head into the key Christmas season will be under the spotlight when J Sainsbury, the supermarket, publishes half-year results. Eurozone industrial production is out at 10.00am UK time and Spain is the latest country to release inflation data at 8.00am. Before we go, a quick round-up of where things stand on stock markets: The FTSE 100 closed down just 1.6 points at 6,726.8. Germany's Dax is down 0.3% to 9,076.5 and in France the CAC40 is off 0.6% at 4,263.8. In the US, the S&P 500 is down 0.3% at 1,767, the Dow Jones industrial average is off 0.3% at 15,729 and the Nasdaq is down 0.3% at 3,908. With that I am signing off for today. We will be back in the morning with rolling coverage of business and economic news. Thanks for reading and for all the comments. While the UK government welcomes a slowdown in inflation today, in the Czech Republic, central bankers have been worrying about deflation. After the Czech national bank's move last week to weaken the country's crown currency, Stephen Lewis, chief economist at Monument Securities has been considering whether it is right to think - as US Fed Chairman Ben Bernanke claimed in November 2002 - that a central bank always could and always should use every device it could imagine to prevent a situation where prices fall, conventionally labelled 'deflation'. Lewis was prompted to consider this, he says, after the Czech central bank (CNB) launched crown sales on the open market for the first time in over a decade last Thursday, to weaken the currency and help stem a slowdown in inflation. Reuters has the deails here. And thanks to business live reader londondavid for highlighting the move on the day. Lewis warns the central bank's policy risks pushing the Czech economy back into recession. "To court that danger simply because US economists of Mr Bernanke's stamp have theoretical notions on how the economy works shows how central bankers are still in awe of old thinking," he says. He comments: CNB policymakers, or at least a majority of them, appear to have judged they could wait no longer in forestalling deflation risks and so decided to implement their fx plan. Deliberately devaluing one's currency is, of course, frowned upon in international circles. Japan has already established a precedent that exchange rate depreciation is fine with the global community if it happens to occur as an unintended consequence of domestic monetary actions. The CNB could hardly find comfort in that, however, since its policy is treating the exchange rate as a target and has involved active intervention on the exchanges to achieve its goal. There is a closer parallel with Switzerland, though the Swiss franc had been appreciating rapidly against the currency of its major trading partner, the euro zone, when the Swiss National Bank decided in September 2011 to cap its rate against the euro at 1.20. The Czech koruna, by contrast, had been fairly stable against the euro for months prior to the CNB's decision. Further, there had been brighter news on the Czech economy, in confidence indices and PMI data, raising doubts in some quarters whether a yet more accommodative monetary policy was needed at all. The CNB justified its policy of fx sales in terms of preventing long-term undershooting of its inflation target. Mr Tomsik, a CNB vice governor, expressed the thinking behind the CNB's move in revealing terms. 'We would be in deflation for a very long period, easily three quarters if not longer, because economic theory shows that it is difficult to crawl out of deflation once you get stuck in it.' It is worth noting that this central banker regards nine months as a 'very long time'. It seems that, for him and his fellow-thinkers, even one month when the consumer price index is lower than in the corresponding month of the previous year is reason for deep concern. Then, there is his appeal to 'economic theory'. To be sure, some textbooks lay it down as indubitable truth that deflation is hard to escape and, as they understand the deflation process, they may be right. But that is not to say that any period when prices happen to fall is to be labelled 'deflationary'. There has, perhaps, been too much focus on Japan's experience, without regard for the special influences affecting that country, in assessing the proper priorities of monetary policy. After all, the USA recorded eight successive months of negative annual CPI inflation in 2009 without identifiable harm. Mr Janacek, a more robust member of the CNB's board, declared prior to last week's policy meeting that he would rather tolerate a few months of moderate 'deflation' than risk shocking the economy with a radical fx policy. We may well suppose the most immediate effect of the fx depreciation will be a rise in Czech import prices and a squeeze on Czech domestic purchasers' spending power. Though consumer prices may not now fall, the CNB's policy risks pushing the Czech economy back into recession. To court that danger simply because US economists of Mr Bernanke's stamp have theoretical notions on how the economy works shows how central bankers are still in awe of old thinking. We shall be watching the Czech experiment closely for the broader implications it might have for monetary management in the advanced economies. After this morning's news of a significant slowdown in UK inflation there were plenty of commentators quick off the mark in noting that at 2.2%, it is still three times the average pace of wage growth. Now comes a separate report suggesting wage growth fell in recent months and another claiming fuel poverty is up. Data from VocaLink, the company that processes the large number of payments for UK workers, underlines the pressure on earnings. It says that despite recent signs of improvement in the UK economy its latest Take Home Pay Index shows that wage growth has slowed. The monthly index shows that pay growth in FTSE 350 companies fell to 2.2% in the three months to the end of October from 2.4% in the three month to end September. Looking at pay sector by sector, it says: Services sector take home pay growth slowed slightly year-on-year in the three months to October – down to 2.5% from 2.7% in the three months to September Annual take home pay in the manufacturing sector fell by 0.7% in the three months to October, following several months of slowing growth However the public sector experienced annual take home pay growth at 0.1% for the first time since March 2013. David Yates, VocaLink's chief executive: This month’s Take Home Pay Index highlights that across multiple sectors wage growth remains sluggish. While inflation has remained steady for over a year, rising prices of essentials are putting pressure on households and recent increases in domestic gas and electricity bills mean household spending continues to be squeezed. With the pace of wage growth slowing, there may be concerns about the prospect of consumer spending worsening as retailers head toward the crucial Christmas sales period. A separate report from Legal & General suggests 1 in 3 households say they will be in fuel poverty this winter, up 53% on the same period last year. That is based on the government’s definition of paying 10% of income on gas and electricity. Its MoneyMood Survey adds: The number of homes across the UK who say they are “In fuel poverty now or will be in the next three months” is 6.8 million, up 2.4 million on the equivalent figure for 2012 (4.4 million). This is significantly higher than the latest Government estimates of 3.2 million homes in fuel poverty, which is based on 2011 data. In many regions the number of households in fuel poverty is even higher. Two regions have almost 1 in 2 in fuel poverty – in the East Midlands 48% say they are in fuel poverty (up 152%). Similarly in the North East 48% of homes are in fuel poverty (up 140%). Over in Greece, word is coming through that ahead of this afternoon's meeting, visiting troika inspectors have been focusing on lifting the blanket ban on repossessions of properties in a bid to rejuvenate the market and as our correspondent in Athens, Helena Smith, says it is a potentially explosive issue. She writes: No subject is quite as neuralgic as that of doing away with the blanket ban on repossessions of properties whose owners owe less than 200,000 euro. In a sign of the mounting tension around the issue, visiting troika inspectors insisted that the prohibition, which is to be in force until 31 December, was the focus of today's talks at the finance ministry. Indicatively, the talks were attended by the heads of Greek banks, the development minister Kostis Hadzidakis, the Justice minister Charalmbos Athanasiou and the finance minister Yannis Stournaras, all of whom are under immense pressure to lift the ban when it effectively ends at the end of the year. The vast majority of non-performing loans are believed to derive from mortgage payers defaulting on their debt with bankers classifying around 30% of borrowers as "strategic defaulters" who can pay but chose not to pay because of other debts they deem more expedient. The ban, passed by a previous socialist government, has in the main been blamed by bankers for the defaults. With lack of liquidity an ever more pressing issue in a market that became lifeless long ago, the troika is pressuring the government to allow banks to auction off homes in the hope it will rejuvenate the Greek property market - one of the first victims of the country's debt crisis. A development ministry official conceded that although the fragile coalition sees the issue as "another red line" - with at least ten MPs resolutely refusing to endorse such a measure in parliament -- the heat was now on for the government to "make a decision by December 15." "What we are trying to do is protect the poor, vulnerable groups who absolutely cannot lose their home," he said. "There is enormous pressure for the issue to be settled by the middle of next month." According to Greece's central bank, first-home owners account for the majority of 100,000 plus mortgages in arrears with officials reporting a leap in numbers in recent months because of a three-year backlog in annual property taxes that property owners have had to pay as part of government efforts to boost revenue. Without a compromise analysts believe prime minister Antonis Samaras' increasingly frail coalition could fall. MPs have said repeatedly they will not allow foreclosures to pass with one saying publicly it will tip the country into civil war. It is early on in the trading day in the US and for now, the main stock market indices are little changed. The Dow Jones industrial average had ended at another record high on Monday of 15,783.1. Here is how things stand: S&P 500 -0.15% at 1,769 Dow Jones industrial average -0.04% at 15,777 Nasdaq -0.11% at 3,915 Our economics editor, Larry Elliott, has been looking at the UK's inflation numbers and says the drop in the rate to 2.2% suggests the cost of living is finally responding to a lack of spending power. He writes: Inflation is in retreat across the west. Although the City of London was focusing on the unexpectedly sharp fall in the UK's cost of living, this was merely part of a general trend from Hungary to Portugal and from Italy to Germany. Deflation is already a reality for some of the troubled countries on the fringes of the eurozone area. Others are heading in that direction. For now, that list does not include Britain where the current inflation rate of 2.2% is still (just) above the government target and higher than the eurozone average, which is already 0.7% and likely to fall lower when new figures are out later this week. But the data from the Office for National Statistics is still significant in three material respects. First, it suggests that the cost of living is finally responding to a lack of spending power... The second point to note - as Labour did - is that the gap between price increases and wage increases remains even after the fall in inflation from 2.7% to 2.2%, because average earnings are growing by less than 1% a year... Finally, falling inflation provides a breathing space for the Bank of England. As Capital Economics notes, the economy is currently in a sweet spot in which price pressures are abating even though the economy is growing at an annual rate of around 3% a year. Read his full story here: Inflation fall shows effects of spending power squeeze In Germany, news is leaking out from the country's "wisemen" panel of economic advisers that they see the economy growing slightly faster than at the time of their spring forecasts. The panel now expects 2013 GDP growth of 0.4%, up from its March estimate of 0.3%, but still below the government's 0.5% forecast, according to the Frankfurter Allgemeine newspaper (in German). Growth in 2014 is seen at 1.6%, again below the government forecast, which is 1.7%. The panel, officially known as the Sachverständigenrat zur Begutachtung der gesamtwirtschaftlichen Entwicklung - or German Council of Economic Experts - is due to hand its annual report to the government tomorrow. The Frankfurter Allgemeine says the report will contain "harsh criticism" of government policies and risks ahead to Europe's largest economy, centred on proposals to introduce a minimum wage, a change stipulated by the Social Democrats (SPD) in coalition building negotiations. Good afternoon. Sticking with the much weaker-than-expected inflation data from the UK, a quick look now at how it is affecting the pound today. Sterling hit a two-month low against the dollar of $1.585 in the wake of the official data this morning as traders were forced to scale back their bets that the Bank of England would have to raise interest rates sooner than it had vowed. There is plenty more news in the pipeline for foreign exchange traders to bet on. Alex Edwards, head of the corporate desk at UKForex comments: Inflation is now sitting closer to [Bank of England governor Mark] Carney's target of 2%, which will perhaps help ease market expectations for an early rate hike from the Bank of England. We'll hear from Carney and the bank tomorrow – it's an important 24 hours for the pound. For now, the pound stands at $1.5914, having recovered some ground against the dollar since the inflation number. Tomorrow morning sees the latest labour market data for the UK at 9.30am. Once a story of primarily human and political importance, the figures have recently been catapulted into the economic indicator major league. Newly arrived Bank of England governor Mark Carney's forward guidance introduced in August uses a threshold of 7% unemployment, before which poliycmakers say they will not consider raising interest rates (barring various knockouts being triggered - lots more detail on that from the Bank here). Unemployment was at 7.7% in last month's release and economists forecast it to hold there in tomorrow's data. And just an hour after that we get Carney's second inflation report at the Bank. The quarterly release contains the Bank's outlook for inflation and growth and is accompanied with a 10.30am press conference. The markets have been quite clearly in disagreement with Carney's forward guidance, choosing to ignore reassurances of how long rates will stay low. It will be interesting to see if the Canadian can convince them to take forward guidance at its word with this latest appearance. Brian Hilliard, economist at Societe Generale in London expects the Bank to "forcefully rebuff calls for early rate increases." The central focus of the market will be on the unemployment rate forecasts. It seems very likely that the MPC will predict that the unemployment rate will reach the 7% threshold towards the end of the three year forecast period. If it does so, it will go to great lengths to reiterate that it will only use that as an occasion to reassess the state of the economy. Especially, if it does not make material increases to the inflation forecasts, it will feel able to resist the pressure for early rate increases. Note also recent developments in other markets. The ECB has just cut rates as it is fearful of inflation falling far below target. That indicates a downside growth risk in the euro area, the UK’s largest export market. The Bank will reiterate what that risk means for the UK. Moreover, there are increasing hints from the Fed that, even once it has started and finished its tapering, it will hold rates unchanged for much longer than previously thought. This is not an international environment that is signalling rate increases. Back to UK inflation -- do you think today's drop in the rising cost of living, to 2.2% year-on-year, is sustainable or just temporary? You can vote here in our new poll: UK inflation falls: is it just a blip? Economists expect energy bills to put pressure on inflation in the coming months The early voting suggests a majority of readers reckon inflation will be heading up again soon. And that's a good moment to hand over to my colleague Katie Allen.... Another photo from Greece, showing riot police detaining a fired cleaning worker protesting outside the finance ministry during today's meeting with troika officials: Our Athens correspondent, Helena Smith, reports that Greece's international lenders caused quite a commotion by accidentally hitting a motorcyclist with their car door today (see previous post for video footage) She writes: For the second time in less than a week, auditors representing Greece’s “troika” of creditors at the EU, ECB and IMF have done what they hate most: making themselves the centre of attention by inadvertently causing waves outside the finance ministry. This time the incident occurred when a car carrying a technical team of visiting inspectors knocked a motorcyclist from his bike only meters away from the front door entrance to the finance ministry on Nikis street. In scenes captured on film by cameramen stationed almost permanently outside the building during auditors’ visits, the helmeted motorcyclist is seen clearly being knocked to the ground when an inspector clips him as he tries to open the backdoor of the vehicle. The auditor sitting to his right gets out to see what has happened before the inspector who has opened the door, with some trepidation, also gets out to see if the cyclist is OK. The meeting to which the auditors were driving has since started but the Greek media is reporting that it still remains unclear whether the cyclist was injured. Regular readers will recall that last week visiting mission chiefs were the focus of protests outside the building when finance ministry cleaners, dismissed in a wave of troika-demanded firings, jeered and heckled inspectors more or less at the very same spot. IMF mission head Poul Thomsen was the target of one protestor last week who threw a barrage of coins at him as he got out of his car. The inspectors were forced to exit the building via an emergency back door entrance when protestors blocked elevators and the front door. Greek authorities have assigned extra police protector to the inspectors with prime minister Antonis Samaras attempting to placate passions by telling Greeks, in his first televised interview, that “we are not at war with the troika.” Over in Greece, a troika official has knocked a motorcyclist off his bike as today's meeting between international lenders and the Greek government got off to a bad start. The unfortunate incident occurred as officials arrived for talks with finance minister Yannis Stournaras. As this video shows, an over-eager passenger in the Troika convoy opened his door as the moped drove past, sending it veering to a sudden halt. The good news is that the victim was reportedly uninjured. Kathimerini reports that there were "disparaging remarks from a few dozen protesters gathered nearby". Today's meeting is focused on Greece's fiscal gap for 2014 -- perhaps the Troika should focus on the gap between their convoy and the pavement. There's a longer video clip here on Keep Talking Greece, which also suggests the culprit should have been detained.... The crowd of protesters in Athens today included cleaning staff who are angry about the government's job cut programme - last week they invaded the finance ministry, forcing the troika to exit via the fire escape. Want to know more about UK inflation? The Guardian's datablog has all the stats, going back to the Attlee government: UK inflation since 1948 This won't ease fears that the eurozone is sliding into deflation - Portugal has reported that prices fell by 0.2% last month compared to October 2012. At -0.2% y/y, the Portuguese Consumer Prices Index was weaker then expected, driven by falling food and energy prices. It was flat month-on-month. Here's my colleague Katie Allen on the news that UK inflation has dropped to a 13-month low: Inflation has dropped to its lowest rate in more than a year, catching financial markets offguard and pushing back bets that interest rates in the UK will rise any time soon. The rise in the cost of living was just 2.2% in October, down from 2.7% the month before as measured on the consumer price index. That was well below City economists' forecasts for 2.5% and almost back at the Bank of England's government-set target of 2%. The fall was driven by cheaper fuel prices and less chunky rises in university tuition fees than this time last year, the Office for National Statistics said. But economists were quick to warn that with energy price hikes on the horizon and average wage growth at just a third of inflation, or 0.7%, consumers would continue to feel big strains on their budgets. More here: Fall in inflation to 2.2% welcomed by government Annalisa Piazza of Newedge Strategy sums up some other key points from the ONS's inflation report: Food prices fell a touch to 3.9% from 4.3% the prior month. As for other services prices, restaurants and hotels inflation rose two tenths to 2.8% in October, a sign that demand for services is actually increasing, leading to some upward pressures on prices. Today's drop in inflation is definitely good news for the Bank of England as risks for inflation in the near term have diminished. Piazza doesn't expect any major changes to the BoE's inflation forecasts tomorrow, when it releases new quarterly estimates. Recent announcement of increases in utilities prices will have to be factored in the the medium term forecasts. Falling inflation has been the story of the day - with German CPI hitting a three-year low of 1.2%, and Hungary's inflation rate dropping to its lowest rate since 1974. The Bond Vigilantes team at M&G sums it up: Catherine McKinnell MP, Labour's Shadow Economic Secretary to the Treasury, has welcomed the drop in inflation - before swiftly pointing out that wages are lagging (as flagged up at 10.21am). McKinnell said: This fall in the inflation rate is welcome, but with prices still rising much faster than wages the cost-of-living crisis under David Cameron continues. And with inflation-busting hikes in energy prices in the pipeline families and pensioners will carry on feeling the squeeze. Labour will act to help people struggling with the rising cost of living by freezing energy bills until 2017 and make work pay by expanding free childcare for working parents. And to help 24 million people on middle and low incomes we also want to introduce a lower 10p starting rate of tax. By opposing all these measures and giving a huge tax cut to people earning over £150,000, David Cameron has shown he's out of touch and only stands up for a privileged few. David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC), agrees that today's inflation data takes the pressure off the Bank of England, and helps firms and individuals. He warns, though, that recent energy tariff rises could push the headline cost of living rate up again. The larger than expected fall in inflation will ease pressures on businesses and consumers, particularly at a time when wages aren’t rising at the same rate. However while we expect inflation to fall further over the next year, this will not be a smooth process. Some of the October declines are likely to be reversed, especially when energy price increases take effect. The UK has been more inflation-prone than other major economies. While latest figures show US inflation at 1.2% and eurozone at 0.7%, ours has been above the 2% target for more than four years. The MPC will see this fall as a sign that there is no short-term need to tighten monetary policy, even though the unemployment threshold is likely to be reached earlier than expected. However, the committee must focus on ensuring price stability to avoid threatening business confidence. The drop in the inflation rate takes some pressure off the Bank of England to consider an interest rate rise, says Rob Carnell of ING. He writes: Falling petrol and diesel prices seemed to have done the most to drag the inflation rate down, and the ongoing softness in Brent Crude prices means there may be a little more of this to come in the months ahead. There was also some price softness in furniture and household items too, though given the strength in the UK housing data is less likely to persist, though imported goods in this area might benefit to some extent from sterling's new found strength. Rising tuition fees mean that government adminstered price rises still add to the inflation total, and recent announcements of price hikes by the energy companies also suggests that this might not be the beginning of a new lower trend in UK inflation, though any dip is welcome, and will lessen the impacts of these looming prices hikes when they begin to come through in the months ahead. Speaking of energy prices, EDF has announced a 3.9% tariff rise -- which is lower than its rivals, but still beating average wage rises and the headline inflation rates. Lots of decent reaction to the news that UK inflation has dropped to a 13-month low. Here's Duncan Weldon, the TUC economist, to kick us off: Even at 2.2%, CPI inflation is still running three times faster than UK wages -- which rose 0.7% year-on-year according to the latest data. The squeeze on living standards continues. The Treasury has hailed the drop in Britain's inflation rate as a sign that the UK economy is on the right track. It even hinted that chancellor George Osborne should get some of the credit, having frozen fuel duty in March's budget. Here's the official statement from an HMT spokesperson: Inflation has fallen to well below half of its peak of 5.2 per cent. With the help of the ongoing freeze in fuel duty that has kept petrol prices 13 pence per litre lower than they otherwise would have been, petrol prices are now at their lowest level since July 2012. Britain’s hard work is paying off and the country is on the path to prosperity. Thanks to the government’s long term economic plan, all parts of the economy are growing, the deficit is falling and jobs are being created - and that's the only sustainable way to raise living standards for hardworking families. But times remain tough for many people so wherever possible we have found the money to freeze fuel duty, freeze council tax and take 2.7 million people out of tax by increasing the tax free personal allowance. The Office for National Statistics explains that transport prices fell by 1.5% between September and October, partly due to lower prices at the pump. The ONS reported: Petrol prices fell by 4.9 pence per litre between September and October this year compared with a fall of 0.9 pence per litre between the same two months a year ago, to stand at 131.6 pence. Diesel prices fell by 2.9 pence per litre between September and October this year compared with a fall of 0.6 pence per litre between the same two months a year ago, to stand at 139.0 pence. There were also notable downward contributions from air fares and prices for second hand cars. And education had less impact on the cost of living compared to a year ago, when tuition fees really jumped. Education costs jumped by 8.2% between September and October 2013,compared with a rise of 19.1% between the same two months in 2012. The ONS again: The downward contribution came principally from UK and EU student tuition fees, where the impact on the CPI of the rise in the cap for tuition fees introduced last year for new UK and EU students in England was smaller this year than in 2012. The smaller impact was due to the fact that many students were already paying the higher rate of fees. In addition there were more modest price increases for part-time and postgraduate fees compared to last year. This graph shows how last month's surprise drop in inflation brings the CPI measure closer to the Bank of England's target of 2%, matching the 13-month low of 2.2% hit in September. The full statement from the ONS on UK inflation is online here. On a monthly basis, the UK consumer prices index crept up by just 0.1% in October compared to September. The big drop in the annual rate of CPI to 2.2% matches the level recorded in September 2012 -- it hasn't been lower in four years..... The UK's Retail Prices Index, a broader measure of inflation used for some pay settlements and welfare calculations, also came in lower than expected. It was recorded at 2.6% year-on-year, down from 3.2% in September. The pound had tumbled over a cent against the US dollar, down 0.8% to $1.5857. It's also dropped to a one-week low against the euro, at €1.1866. Curiously, the pound was dropping in the seconds leading up to 9.30am - when the data was released. The core UK inflation rate, which excludes energy, food, alcohol and tobacco, came in at 1.7% - the lowest rate since September 2009. The drop in UK inflation last month was mainly due to lower prices for motor fuel, air fares, second-hand cars and university tuition, according to the Office for National Statistics. Breaking: UK inflation has dropped to its lowest level since September 2012. The Consumer Prices index came in at just 2.2% in October, tumbling from 2.7% the previous month and much lower than economists had expected. More to follow! Back to eurozone inflation....and Austria's central bank governor, Ewald Nowotny, has warned that stagnation is the bigger threat. Reuters has the details: Stalling economy is a bigger risk to the euro zone than rapidly rising prices, European Central Bank Governing Council member Ewald Nowotny said on Tuesday. The ECB cut its main refinancing rate to a record low of 0.25% on Thursday after October inflation came in at 0.7%, well below the central bank's target of below, but close to 2%. "It's not the inflation that is the danger, it's stagnation that is the real danger," Nowotny said at an event organised by Pioneer Investments. Nowotny, who also heads the Austrian central bank, said that there is no north-south split at the Governing Council. Reuters reported on Thursday that about a quarter of policymakers, led by Bundesbank President Jens Weidmann, opposed Thursday's interest rate cut. On Greece, Bloomberg flags up that finance minister Yannis Stournaras has two meetings today with officials from the International Monetary Fund, the ECB and the EC. The Kathimerini newspaper reports that the first meeting will include Bank of Greece officials, and will focus on plans to lift a ban on foreclosures (ie housing repossessions -- as NDMann kindly flags up in the comments). The second meeting will concentrate on Greece's budget shortfall in 2014. It was a cracking story while it lasted, but it appears that London's Walkie Scorchie tower will soon be fixed. The 'fryscraper', on Fenchurch Street, hit the headlines after locals spotted that its curved exterior was shining blinding rays of sunlight down to the pavement below, melting part of a Jaguar parked below. One intrepid reporter managed to fry an egg in the glare, while a local barber's reported that its doormat caught fire from the effects of the building (which was originally nicknamed the Walkie Talkie because of its shape). It's not a problem today, of course, with London gripped by autumnal gloom. But Land Securities says it's confident that a solution will be in place before the sun reappears sometime in 2014. It told shareholders this morning that: At 20 Fenchurch Street, our landmark tower in the City, we have continued to attract new tenants and the building is now 56% pre-let, with a further 20% in solicitors' hands. Despite the solar glare issue of the summer, occupiers have not been blinded* to the efficiency and location of the building. We are close to resolving the issue and it will not delay occupation nor inflate budgeted costs. * - we'll do the weak puns, thanks guys Inflation is also dropping in Hungary - where the consumer prices index dropped to just 0.9% year on year in October. That, according to Reuters, is the lowest level since 1974. It's a big fall on September's 1.4%, due to falling fuel and food prices (core inflation, which strips both costs out, was 3.4% year on year) At just 1.2% in October, Germany's annual inflation rate hasn't been lower since August 2010 when CPI was just 1.0%. Today's reading matches April's rate (so strictly speaking this is the joint lowest rate in three years). This chart shows the details: While our friends at fast FT also produced a nifty graph: (their take on the German inflation is here). New economic forecasts from the Bank of France this morning. It predicts that the French economy will grow by 0.4% in the final three months of 2013. We find out on Thursday how France performed in the third quarter of this year, when new eurozone GDP data is released. Economists reckon that French output rose by a mere 0.1% in Q3, a slowdown from the 0.5% recorded between April and June. With S&P downgrading France last week, it could use a bounceback in the run-up to Christmas. This morning's UK inflation data is expected to show that energy prices dropped a little last month. A fall in petrol prices is one of the key factors behind expectations for the Consumer Prices Index (CPI) for October easing to around 2.5%, down from a rate of 2.7% in September. ... The ONS figures will show inflation staying stubbornly above its 2% target – and continuing to squeeze incomes as the cost of living rises. Inflation is expected to carry on falling from its 2.9% high in June. The rate was 2.4% in April. More here: UK inflation rate expected to fall in new CPI report Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of events across the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world. Inflation is top of the agenda today, with new measures of the cost of living in both the UK and Germany being released. The German data is already out, confirming that its inflation rate has fallen to its lowest rate in three years. The cost of living rose by 1.2% in October on an annual basis, down from 1.4% in September, and the lowest level since August 2010. It fell by 0.2% month-on-month. Falling oil prices are one cause. In another sign that the eurozone economy is weak, wholesale prices in Germany were 2.7% lower than a year ago, dropping 1.0% month-on-month. It confirms that the European Central Bank was right to cut interest rates to a new record low last week -- a move that was not welcomed in Germany. Here's some instant reaction: We get Britain's inflation data at 9.30am GMT. It's also expected to drop, but not to Germanic levels. Analysts predict that the UK Consumer Prices Index will fall to 2.5% in October, from 2.7%. As Michael Hewson of CMC Markets puts it: While concerns about falling prices appear to be raising concerns in Europe, there is no such concern in the UK, with the latest October CPI numbers expected to show a year on year drop from 2.7% to 2.5%. The month on month figure is expected to show a rise of 0.4%, partly as a result of rising energy bills not being totally offset by a fall in petrol prices. Retail prices are still rising at 3% a year with a month on month rise of 0.5%. And with wages rising around 1% per year, a small fall in inflation will bring little relief to workers. Elsewhere....the Greek government will resume talks with its international lenders over its bailout programme. In the corporate world, Vodafone has announced details of a £7bn investment programme after reporting a drop in revenues. Europe's weak economy gets the blame.... And it looks like a quiet start in the City. I'll be tracking all the developments through the day as usual.
fields.headline: UK inflation rate hits 13-month low of 2.2% - as it happened
fields.trailText: Cost of living in the UK rose by just 2.2% year on year in October, lower than economists had predicted but still way behind wage rises

webTitle: Walmart meets backlash over earlier Thanksgiving day opening

fields.standfirst: Retail giant will open stores at 6pm on Thanksgiving, two hours earlier than 2012 opening which prompted growing furore
fields.body:
Walmart will open its stores at 6pm on this year's Thanksgiving holiday, two hours earlier than last year, the company said on Tuesday as US retailers faced a mounting backlash over their holiday plans.

Last year Walmart faced protests nationwide when for the first time it opened its doors on Thanksgiving. The retail giant has been joined by a long list of companies now opening on the holiday including Kmart, Target and Macy’s, which will open on Thanksgiving for the first time this year.

The Thanksgiving holiday comes one day before Black Friday, the traditional start of the Christmas shopping season. “Black Friday is our day – our Super Bowl – and we’re ready to prove once again that no one does it better than Walmart,” said Bill Simon, president and CEO of Walmart US. “We’re excited to give our customers an incredible Black Friday with shopping hours that will allow them to take advantage of great prices on Thanksgiving night and all weekend long.”

Sears and Kmart stores have set out plans to open Thanksgiving Day, with Kmart opening at 6am and remaining open for 41 hours straight through Black Friday. Kmart's plans have attracted a backlash on Facebook, where shoppers have vowed to boycott the store in protest.

One critic, Heather Miller, wrote: “Really Kmart 6am on Thanksgiving?! No consideration for your employees and their families! Everyone should be home with their families instead of supporting all these greedy stores opening on Thanksgiving!”

Walmart plans to soften the holiday blow to its estimated million workers by offering them an extra day’s pay, discount shopping and a holiday meal in store during their shift.

The union-backed employee group OUR WalMart is planning a series of protests in the run-up to Thanksgiving. The group is calling on the company to use its $17bn in profits to pay a minimum of $25,000 a year for full-time work and to end what it claims is illegal retaliation against workers who protest pay and conditions. The group recently organised a strike in Los Angeles over what they called WalMart’s "poverty wages". The action led to more than 50 arrests. Our WalMart has written to President Barack Obama, asking him to meet with protesting workers and claiming the company is “helping to hold America back from this dream”.

OUR Walmart member Richard Reynoso said: “Personally, I don’t know my schedule yet for Thanksgiving. Of course I hope I get to spend the holiday with my family.

“I am sorry to see other retailers continue to follow WalMart's shortsighted lead in forcing retail workers to cut Thanksgiving short with their families and in driving down wages across the industry. This is why changing WalMart is so important to workers at Walmart and all American workers. My co-workers and I are calling for changes that impact us year-round, not just during the holiday season.”

webTitle: Online fashion retailer Asos launches Chinese website

fields.standfirst: Asos China is eighth country-specific website for e-tailer, which delivers to 237 countries and territories
fields.body:
Fashion website Asos is aiming to tap into the fast-growing Chinese market with the launch of a dedicated website for the country.

"China continues to impress us with its steady growth. The launch will not only help navigate and break down existing barriers, but also dramatically improve the Asos experience for our fast-growing number of Chinese customers," said Nick Robertson, the chief executive.

Asos China is the eighth country-specific site for the e-tailer, which has seen the value of its shares nearly treble to £57.32 in the past year amid soaring sales. Sales are expected to break through the £1bn barrier this financial year as the company benefits from shoppers' switch to the internet and rapid expansion overseas. Asos, which delivers to 237 countries and territories and sells more than 65,000 products, made a profit before tax of £54.7m in the year to August, up 37% on the year before, while sales rose 40% to £753.8m.

Asos China will launch with just 2,000 products, rising to more than 6,000 priced in local currency by spring 2014. It will include both womenswear and menswear. It will stock the Asos own label and gradually introduce brands at all price levels including American Apparel, Mango, Ted Baker and Sonia by Sonia Rykiel.

The launch, on which Asos is spending up to £6m this year, will be supported by local editorial content and newsletters in a bid to drive traffic on Chinese social media sites such as Sina Weibo, in the same way that Asos has prospered from using western sites such as Twitter and Facebook.

• This article was amended on 15 November 2013. An earlier version said Asos operates in 237 countries.

webTitle: Royal Bank of Scotland faces further fines over sub-prime mortgage crisis

fields.bodyText: Royal Bank of Scotland is still facing potentially painful penalties from the US authorities over the sub-prime mortgage crisis, the Treasury select committee of MPs was warned on Tuesday. Already hit by a £390m fine for rigging Libor and in discussions with regulators over an investigation into potential currency rigging, the bank has been forced to hold more capital by the Bank of England because of the possibility of further fines, MPs were told by Robin Budenberg, the outgoing chairman of UK Financial Investments (UKFI). Budenberg, who was challenged about the influence the Treasury has over the body which was set up look after the stakes in the bailed out banks, said mortgage trading was one of the outstanding issues RBS faces. He made reference to JP Morgan, which has paid £8bn to settle a number of regulators' claims it missold mortgages. "We've asked them where they feel their exposures are and clearly there are a range of regulatory issues that are pending," Budenberg said. Earlier this month RBS admitted it was holding more capital and putting £38bn of its most troublesome loans into an internal bad bank after a review commissioned by George Osborne ruled out a full-blown standalone bad bank. Budenberg admitted he had accelerated Stephen Hester's departure from RBS in September. The MPs were told that UKFI had not seen opportunities for a sale of the 81% government stake in RBS in the last two years – which appeared to contradict remarks by the bank a year ago when it raised the possibility of sale in 2014. Budenberg's successor, James Leigh-Pemberton, indicated that the average price at which the taxpayer bought its stake in RBS – 502p – would not be the only consideration when deciding whether to sell any shares. "It is difficult not to take it into account but it can't be the only consideration, because when we make our recommendations we also provide it in the context of whether there is an opportunity to realise fair value or more than fair value ," he said. Leigh-Pemberton said it was "very, very difficult to say with any precision" when a sale of RBS could begin, and it would not be before the £1.5bn dividend access share, which allows the government to receive dividends before other shareholders, is removed. To demonstrate UKFI's independence from Osborne, Budenberg said he had resisted deep cuts to bonuses suggested by the chancellor on the grounds the reductions were not "commercially acceptable". Budenberg also cited UKFI's influence in convincing Osborne not to force RBS to sell off its US arm, Citizens, too quickly. Citizens is to be spun off next year, probably through a stock market flotation. "Our view has always been that we need to give Citizens time to recover in terms of its financial performance, and now is a time to begin that process," said Budenberg. He is to leave at the end of the year after overseeing the sale of the first part of the stake in Lloyds – 4.2bn shares worth £3.2bn – in September at a price of 75p a share. Budenberg said the government could raise another 0.5p per share, or £21m, if more short-term investors, such as hedge funds, had been allowed to participate in the sale. Budenberg said that UKFI wanted to show it was a responsible seller and that it does not "just sell to the highest bidder". Further details would be released by the National Audit Office, Budenberg said.

webTitle: Walkie-Scorchie problems nearly fixed, Land Securities says

fields.standfirst: Chief executive Robert Noel said the problems at the building, which made news for its solar glare over the summer, would not delay tenants moving in
fields.body:
Property company Land Securities said it was close to fixing the problems at its Walkie-Talkie City skyscraper after the glare from the building melted car parts on the street below over the summer.

Chief executive Robert Noel said the problems at the building, which is still under construction, would not delay tenants moving in or exceed the budget set aside for its £240m share of the development.

"A solution is in the final stages of design and implementation will commence shortly. Despite the solar glare issue of the summer, occupiers have not been blinded to the efficiency and location of the building. We are close to resolving the issue and it will not delay occupation nor inflate budgeted cost," he said.

The glare from the 37-storey building, officially known as 20 Fenchurch Street but which has now been nicknamed the "Walkie-Scorchie", was so strong that a motorist claimed it melted part of his Jaguar parked on the street below.

Business owners in the area said the reflected sun rays caused paintwork to blister and tiles to crack, while others proved the heat was so intense it was possible to fry an egg.

Noel said that the solar shading solution would be installed when the weather improved, and in time for when office workers move in next year in September.

Land Securities is in a joint venture with Canary Wharf Group on the scheme, designed by the architect Rafael Viñoly.

Viñoly said in September he predicted the building might reflect hot sun rays to the street below but "didn't realise it was going to be so hot".

The building is 56% pre-let, with negotiations on a further 20% of space close to completion.

In terms of Land Securities' retail portfolio, Noel said while there were signs the UK economy was improving and "the retail market has turned a corner", consumers remained under pressure.

"Although there is improvement in the UK economy, headwinds persist in retail property as we believe the consumer, with lower real income and faced with rising non-discretionary expenditure, will remain under pressure.

"With an increasing population and healthy demand in all sectors, we view London property as distinct, although not divorced, from the overall UK economy."

Announcing first-half results for the six months to 30 September, he said net assets per share – a key measure for property companies – rose 3.6% to 994p from 31 March.

The rise was driven by an increase in value of its portfolio and profits on disposals. Underlying earnings increased 8.9% to £156.5m.

He said the market was "highly competitive", which meant sales of assets would likely exceed spending and acquisitions in the second half.

"It is likely that revenue profit will be slightly lower than in the first half as we lose income from sales."

Land Securities opened its latest shopping centre, Trinity Leeds, in March, with plans underway for new retail schemes in Glasgow, Oxford and Guildford.

The company announced that Sir Stuart Rose, the former chief executive of Marks & Spencer, will step down as a non-executive director in January.

At the same time Cressida Hogg, the managing partner of infrastructure at 3i, and Edward Bonham Carter, chief executive at Jupiter Fund Management, will join as non-executive directors.

The company recommended a first-half dividend of 15.2p a share, up 2.7%.

webTitle: Energy companies shouldn't treat customers as 'cash cows', says Davey

fields.standfirst: Energy secretary Ed Davey tells industry conference that latest round of price rises 'have not been fully and openly justified'
fields.body:
Ed Davey, the secretary of state for energy and climate change, has accused the big six energy companies of using customers as "cash cows" by raising bills unfairly.

But he also renewed his attack on Ed Miliband, describing the Labour leader's proposal to freeze energy prices as "intellectually bankrupt".

Davey was speaking at the annual conference of Energy UK, the lobby group for the power industry, on the day in which EDF became the latest firm to raise prices.

He noted the rise by the French group was more "modest" than others but urged consumers to vote with their feet by switching to cheaper suppliers. "Customers are not just cash cows to be squeezed in the pursuit of a higher return for shareholders," he said. "And frankly, the latest round of bill rises have not been fully and openly justified."

Davey said the energy industry faced a "Fred the Shred" moment where they could take action to be more responsible or risk being pilloried like the banks – specifically the former RBS boss Fred Goodwin.

But Davey was even more critical of Miliband, saying many of the problems that he was trying to sort out had been left on his plate by the former energy secretary. Davey said Miliband "should know better" than to play to newspaper headlines with "quick fixes" such as a price freeze.

Davey said he was absalutely clear that the role of government was not to fix prices. "This will have a huge detrimental impact on the investment we need to deliver secure energy supplies. And an investment squeeze would mean a huge black hole in Britain's energy security – risking blackouts and higher prices in the long run," he argued.

Davey admitted he was put under pressure by power companies to lift energy efficiency measures and other costs off bills. "Quite a few people have been trying to put pressure on the government," he said.

webTitle: Virgin Wines' UK business in £14m management buyout

fields.standfirst: Former owner Direct Wines to focus on expansion overseas
fields.body:
Virgin Wines' UK business has been bought out by its management as former owner Direct Wines focuses on overseas expansion.

The management team, led by Jay Wright and backed by private equity funds Mobeus Equity Partners and Connection Capital, has paid around £14m for the business.

Sales at the UK business totalled £35m in the year to June 2013, and Wright said the plan was to build on growth achieved since he took charge in 2008, targeting £50m of sales over the next four to five years.

Wright founded Warehouse Wines in 2000 and sold it to Direct Wines in 2002, before merging it with Virgin Wines in 2008.

He said that while the management and owners of Direct Wines had been supportive, "my passion is to work for myself.

"It's a fabulous opportunity to do everything the way we want to do it. Strategically we are looking at much faster growth," he said.

Plans include an extension of its "try before you buy" offering through wine tastings.

Virgin Wines employs around 160 people in the UK, with a distribution and packing operation in Preston and back office functions in Norwich.

Simon McMurtrie, chief executive of Direct Wines, said the group would now focus on expansion in the United States and Australia, as well as on its Laithwaite's Wine business in the UK. Direct Wines was founded by Tony Laithwaite in 1969 and is still family-owned. It has annual sales of around £350m.

"The board of the Direct Wines group and our shareholders, the Laithwaite family, want us to accelerate our growth in the US, Australia and in our core Laithwaite's Wine business in the UK and that is where we are now focusing our investment," McMurtrie said.

He added Direct Wines had retained Virgin Wines in the US and Australia "where they play a key role in the development of our businesses in those two markets".

webTitle: Inflation fall shows effects of spending power squeeze

fields.standfirst: Drop in rate of UK inflation to 2.2% suggests cost of living finally responding to lack of spending power
fields.body:
Inflation is in retreat across the west. Although the City of London was focusing on the unexpectedly sharp fall in the UK's cost of living, this was merely part of a general trend from Hungary to Portugal and from Italy to Germany. Deflation is already a reality for some of the troubled countries on the fringes of the eurozone area. Others are heading in that direction.

For now, that list does not include Britain where the current inflation rate of 2.2% is still (just) above the government target and higher than the eurozone average, which is already 0.7% and likely to fall lower when new figures are out later this week.

But The latest inflation data from the Office for National Statistics is still significant in three material respects. First, it suggests that the cost of living is finally responding to a lack of spending power. Inflation in the UK has proved "sticky" – staying high even during the period when the economy was barely growing. In part, that was due to a fall in the value of the pound, which made imports dearer. In part, it was caused by higher-than-inflation increases in "administered" prices: cost increases such as rail fares that are set either by the state or by regulators.

The latest data may help to dispel fears that Britain is somehow hardwired to have above-target inflation whatever the circumstances. Core inflation – which excludes volatile energy prices – is currently 1.7%, its lowest for four years. Companies are finding it hard to make price increases stick in an environment where consumers are seeing their real incomes squeezed year after year.

Falling inflation matters politically. The second point to note- as Labour did - is that the gap between price rises and wage increases remains even after the fall in inflation from 2.7% to 2.2%, because average earnings are growing by less than 1% a year. But the Bank of England expects pay awards to edge up next year as a growing economy increases the demand for labour. ONS data for producer prices shows that inflationary pressure in the pipeline is weak, so there is a chance that in 2014 downward pressure on the cost of living and a pick up in average earnings will lead to real incomes rising. webTitle: New Look seeks expansion in Europe and China after returning to profit

fields.standfirst: Budget fashion retailer plans to open 21 stores in China by end of next year and rules out stock market flotation
fields.body:
New Look has revealed plans to step up expansion in China, Russia, Poland and Germany despite "challenging trading" at home.

The low-price fashion retailer posted a return to the black with half-year profits to the end of September of £13.8m, compared with a loss of £13.6m a year ago. The company said it added more fashionable products, reduced discounting and tempted shoppers to buy more expensive items.

A 78.8% rise in online sales helped deliver a 6% increase in revenues to £753.2m with underlying sales in the UK up 2.6%.

The company said fur-lined parkas, oversized "boyfriend" coats and boots of all kinds were currently driving sales.

But Anders Kristiansen, New Look's chief executive, said trading had been difficult since September as the benefits of the economic recovery were not being fed through to customers. A warm autumn was also hitting sales. "It's pretty tough out there," he said.

In that environment, Kristiansen said New Look would not seek to raise money via the stock market for at least a year, despite a new appetite for retail stocks. Bonmarché and Poundland are expected to follow the example of Wine Rack owner Conviviality Retail with London listings in the next few months.

"At the moment we are focused on executing our strategy and we need to continue to deliver that. [An IPO] is not something on our mind at the moment," he said.

The departure of New Look's long-term finance director, Alastair Miller, who announced he will leave the company once a successor has been found, is also likely to put major fundraising on hold. Miller is leaving to build a "portfolio career" working with a number of different businesses.

New Look is aiming to build its international presence in four key markets, and plans to enter China for the first time in the spring. Kristiansen said the company had already signed up six stores in shopping malls in and around Beijing and Shanghai, with another 15 that should be open by the end of next year.

In Poland, New Look wants to buy out its local franchise partner and in Russia it is aiming to move from a franchise to a joint-venture so it can accelerate expansion. In Germany New Look has 10 concessions in department stores but now wants to open its own stores.

In all four markets – and France, where New Look owns the Mim chain – the retailer is also planning to open local language websites after enjoying success via Asos, the online fashion store, where sales rose 78% during the half, with two-thirds of sales overseas.

webTitle: Just Retirement to make £1.1bn stock market return

fields.standfirst: The provider of pensions to retirees with health problems is selling a 30.5% stake at 225p a share
fields.body:
Just Retirement, the provider of pensions to retirees with health problems, will return to the stock market valued at £1.1bn.

The British company is selling a 30.5% stake, or 152m shares priced at 225p in Tuesday's listing, in the middle of its original range of between 200p and 250p a share.

It was previously listed on Aim before being bought by a vehicle backed by private equity firm Permira in 2009.

The sale on Tuesday is expected to raise up to £394.7m if there is a maximum take-up of the shares.

Rodney Cook, the company's chief executive, said: "We are delighted investors have responded so positively to the strength of our differentiated business model and proprietary intellectual property.

"We look forward to executing our growth strategy as a listed company and bringing increasing value to our customers and shareholders as we introduce further innovation into the retirement income market."

Full trading of the shares on the main market is expected to start on Friday 15 November.

The company's directors and senior management will own around 2.2% of the listed company.

Its main shareholder Avallux, which is wholly owned by buyout firm Permira, will retain 57.8% if the maximum number of shares is sold.

webTitle: Oxford Instruments gains ground as it makes £160m bid for camera group Andor

fields.standfirst: Updated: Andor shareholder says bid undervalues the prospects of the business
fields.body:
Oxford Instruments has jumped 13% after the industrial group issued an upbeat trading statement and unveiled a £160m bid for Belfast-based Andor Technology.

It is offering 500p a share for Andor, which specialises in scientific digital cameras, but the move was greeted coolly. Andor said it first received an indicative cash offer on 9 July, and this was since raised by 19% to 500p, with talks continuing. Oxford also reserved the right to make a less favourable offer, Andor said. It added:

The board is disappointed that, having only made the indicative proposal on 8 November, Oxford Instruments has chosen to make today's announcement which the board considers to be premature and unhelpful in light of ongoing discussions.
Given the level of uncertainty and conditionality, the board felt it could not properly consider the proposal, but it did confirm to Oxford that it remained willing to continue discussions.

Andor jumped 21% to 487p while Oxford - which also announced the acquisition of a small UK spectrography business, RMG Technology - has added 157p to £13.84. Analysts at Numis said:

Oxford released its interim results highlighting improving trading conditions through the first half of the year. The results were slightly ahead of our expectations and now help underpin full year expectations. Additionally, Oxford announced an approach for Andor Technology at 500p, or £160m, which the Andor board is considering.
We retain our positive stance as we believe that Oxford is a high quality business that possesses defensive characteristics. Structural demand for Oxford's product portfolio is apparent and we believe that these factors, along with new products, technology upgrades and market share gains, position Oxford strongly to grow in excess of general global GDP growth. Andor specialises in high performance digital cameras used primarily in research applications including medical, toxicology, food quality and defence. It sells into many of the same end markets as Oxford suggesting good synergy benefits. Oxford still has to complete due diligence and the Andor board is considering the offer. We estimate that this deal would be around 5% earnings enhancing and will leave net debt of around £100m.

N+1 Singer was less positive, seeing the Andor move as expensive:

While the prospects appear to be improving for Oxford Instruments relative to the first half, we continue to expect an unattractive profile of reported earnings per share growth relative to peers over the next year. The acquisition of Andor could transform this profile, but the indicated price appears high.

But Ben Bourne at Liberum Capital was not worried by this:

At first glance the bid looks expensive (23 times 2014 earnings per share) but management have a strong track record of creating value.

Updated:

Oxford Instruments said it believed its 500p cash offer was an attractive proposal to Andor shareholders and it looked forward to continuing discussions with the board.

But one shareholder at least disagrees. SVG Investment Managers, which owns 2.6% of Andor, said:

We believe [Andor's] sales and margins are at a low point in the cycle, but prospects are likely to improve through 2014 as new products gain traction and markets recover through late 2014 and 2015.
We do not believe that Oxford Instruments' bid premium reflects the quality or long term earnings growth potential. There is a risk the company is sold at a price which could look like a bargain in the medium term. We would expect additional interest in Andor from overseas trade buyers who see this as a very rare opportunity to acquire a business of this quality.

webTitle: UK inflation falls in October: what the economists say

fields.standfirst: Economists say that while lower inflation is good news for Britain's nascent recovery, tprice pressures could tick higher again
fields.body:
Inflation has fallen to its lowest pace in a year and at 2.2% in October was well below economists' forecasts for 2.5%.

The Office for National Statistics said the fall was largely driven by lower fuel prices. Economists said that while lower inflation was good news for Britain's nascent recovery, there were risks that price pressures could tick higher again in coming months and it would be some time before wage hikes caught up.

Here are reactions to the data:

David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce

The larger-than-expected fall in inflation will ease pressures on businesses and consumers, particularly at a time when wages aren't rising at the same rate. However, while we expect inflation to fall further over the next year, this will not be a smooth process. Some of the October declines are likely to be reversed, especially when energy price increases take effect.

The UK has been more inflation-prone than other major economies. While latest figures show US inflation at 1.2% and eurozone at 0.7%, ours has been above the 2% target for more than four years.

Rob Carnell, economist at ING Financial Markets

With the UK inflation report due tomorrow, today's release may take some of the pressure off the Bank of England to substantially alter their previous, and by now, not very credible guidance for a first hike in Bank Rate in mid 2016. Tomorrow's labour market report will also be critical in any change to the policy guidance, and if we see further falls in the unemployment rate, this could trump any improvement in the inflation backdrop suggested by today's figures.

Howard Archer, chief UK and European economist at IHS Global Insight

The marked dip in inflation to 2.2% in October eases the squeeze on consumers' purchasing power, which is helpful to growth prospects. Nevertheless, the squeeze on consumers' purchasing power remains appreciable given that inflation at 2.2% in October is still running at three times average annual earnings growth of 0.7% in the three months to August. This fuels doubts as to whether consumers will be able, or willing, to keep spending at a decent clip over the coming months. If they do, the concern is that it will be through many of them building up debt, although rising employment is helping matters.

While earnings growth seems likely to pick up gradually over the coming months, inflation may well hover close to 2.5% for a while, so it could well take to mid-2014 at least before earnings growth finally overtakes consumer price inflation.

Rob Wood, chief UK economist at Berenberg bank

Britain is slowly but surely getting past the worst of its troubles. Domestic price pressures are subdued and we do not expect rapid consumer price rises to deal the knock-out blow to the Bank of England's forward guidance.

Utility price hikes will stop inflation from falling much further in the next few months. But with productivity improving and sterling higher, inflation should fall towards the Bank of England's target through next year easing the squeeze on people's pay. That helps drive our above consensus growth call of 2.6% for 2014. It is not impossible that real wages begin rising again by the middle of next year.

Martin Beck, UK economist at Capital Economics

Looking forward, inflation may tick up a touch in November as some of the recent announcements of hefty increases in energy prices start to take effect. But if rumours of government action to reduce energy prices in December's autumn statement are correct, this upward pressure could be short-lived. Meanwhile, underlying pressures are likely to remain subdued in response to weak cost pressures and spare capacity. So there seems little risk of the inflation 'knockout' to forward guidance being triggered anytime soon.

Jeremy Cook, chief economist at foreign exchange providers, World First

Sterling has been hit hard by the number as the market looks at three potential outcomes. Firstly, interest rates are likely to remain lower for longer if inflation poses even less of a concern to forward guidance. Secondly, more QE could be used if the Bank believes that inflation has fallen too much. And, finally, how will a lower pound affect trade flows – as exports become cheaper."

Andy Scott, associate director at foreign currency specialists HiFX

Sterling fell across the board Tuesday morning following the release of consumer price inflation data for October which showed prices increasing at the slowest pace since September 2012 … Whilst in the short term this is slightly sterling negative, it is another positive overall for the economy and the impact on sterling should be fairly short lived.

Alex Edwards, head of the corporate desk at UKForex

Inflation is now sitting closer to [Bank of England governor Mark] Carney's target of 2%, which will perhaps help ease market expectations for an early rate hike from the Bank of England. We'll hear from Carney and the bank tomorrow – it's an important 24 hours for the pound.

Treasury spokesperson

Inflation has fallen to well below half of its peak of 5.2%. With the help of the ongoing freeze in fuel duty that has kept petrol prices 13 pence per litre lower than they otherwise would have been, petrol prices are now at their lowest level since July 2012.

Britain's hard work is paying off and the country is on the path to prosperity. Thanks to the government's long term economic plan, all parts of the economy are growing, the deficit is falling and jobs are being created - and that's the only sustainable way to raise living standards for hardworking families.

Catherine McKinnell, shadow economic secretary to the Treasury

This fall in the inflation rate is welcome, but with prices still rising much faster than wages the cost-of-living crisis under David Cameron continues. And with inflation-busting hikes in energy prices in the pipeline families and pensioners will carry on feeling the squeeze.

Labour will act to help people struggling with the rising cost of living by freezing energy bills until 2017 and make work pay by expanding free childcare for working parents. And to help 24 million people on middle and low incomes we also want to introduce a lower 10p starting rate of tax.

webTitle: Fall in inflation to 2.2% welcomed by government

fields.bodyText: Inflation has dropped to its lowest rate in more than a year, catching financial markets offguard and scaling back bets that interest rates in the UK will rise any time soon. The rise in the cost of living was just 2.2% in October, down from 2.7% in September as measured on the consumer price index (CPI). That was well below City economists' forecasts for 2.5% and almost back at the Bank of England's government-set target of 2%. The fall was driven by cheaper fuel prices and less chunky rises in university tuition fees than this time last year, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said. However, economists were quick to warn that with energy price hikes on the horizon and average wage growth at just a third of inflation, or 0.7%, consumers would continue to suffer major strains on their budgets. The government was quick to welcome the news, while experts said the fall, together with a drop in the less volatile core measure of inflation to a four-year low, was good news for the UK's nascent recovery. "The easing in the rate of inflation and underlying price pressures will provide greater scope for monetary policy to be kept looser for longer and thereby helping ensure a sustainable upturn in the economy," said Chris Williamson, chief economist at data specialists Markit. "Lower inflation reduces the risk of the Bank of England having to hike rates earlier than it may otherwise prefer to, allowing policy to focus on stimulating growth rather than warding off rising inflationary pressures." The surprise drop in inflation pushed the pound down against other currencies, hitting a two-month low against the dollar at $1.585 with traders forced to scale back their bets that the Bank would have to raise interest rates sooner than it had pledged. Inflation was even lower than the Bank itself had been forecasting and policymakers are likely to change their outlook at their quarterly inflation report on Wednesday. . Economists said that while energy bill hikes could push inflation back up, it was unlikely inflationary pressures would force the BoE to abandon the path it has set out for low interest rates under recently introduced forward guidance. Under that scheme, policymakers said they will not consider raising interest rates from the record low of 0.5% until at least a threshold of 7% unemployment. Unemployment was 7.7% in the latest data. "October's appreciable retreat in inflation will be welcomed by the Bank of England and it seemingly dilutes the risk that the knockout clauses to its forward guidance could be triggered," said Howard Archer, economist at IHS Global Insight, adding that the Bank is most likely to start raising interest rates "in the latter months of 2015". Experts said the Bank would also take reassurance from other measures of inflation that suggested so-called "pipeline pressures" from manufacturers' costs were easing as well as the less volatile cost of living indicators. Core inflation, which excludes volatile items such as energy, food, alcohol and tobacco, eased to 1.7% from 2.2%, the slowest pace since 2009. Factory gate prices rose just 0.8%, also the slowest inflation for four years, according to separate ONS data released this morning. The inflation slowdown was welcomed by the Treasury, which is putting the final touches to its latest round of budget measures in early December's autumn statement. webTitle: Royal Bank of Scotland slips after downbeat broker notes

fields.standfirst: Nomura repeats reduce recommendation on bank while Goldman cuts its rating
fields.body:
Royal Bank of Scotland is among the fallers after analysts at Nomura repeated their reduce recommendation, albeit edging up their price target, and Goldman cut its rating.

Nomura said investors needed to be patient to see a recovery at RBS - which has set up an internal good and bad bank - and there was potential for disappointment. Analyst Chintan Joshi said:

RBS's future value is driven by its core profitability. We extend our estimates to 2018, and expect group return on tangible equity to improve from around 6.5%-7% in 2015 to around 12.5% in 2018. Valuations based on 2018 estimates, when discounted to today, offer modest upside. However, a lot can change on such horizons, and valuations are very sensitive to assumptions. We do not see investors willing to look forward five years, and on a three-year outlook we still see material downside from current levels.
Looking through to 2016, we see core earnings per share excluding [US subsidiary] Citizens Financial Group at 34.2p, which puts RBS on a valuation of around 340p. We also expect dividends and excess capital per share of 12.4p and 31p, respectively. If we discount this to today, we see RBS's fair value at 285p. Litigation charges in excess of £6bn by 2018, Citizens' sale below 1.1 times price to book value, restructuring charges not yet announced, and changes to macro sentiment create downside risk. We retain our reduce rating and prefer Barclays, which trades on similar valuations with better return on equity levels.

With all that, Nomura has lifted its price target from 270p to 285p.

At the same time, Goldman Sachs has moved from buy to neutral. In the market RBS has lost 7.2p to 332.6p.

These new recommendations come just a day after analysts at Jefferies raised their price target on RBS from 390p to 441p, so it is safe to say there is a wide range of views on the bank in the City.

Lower down the market, John Menzies has dropped 60.5p to 759p after it said poor trading in its distribution business would lead to lower than expected full year profits. Mike Murphy at Numis said:

The third quarter statement confirms continued progress in the Aviation Services division but the Distribution operations were below expectations due to weaker than expected ancillary services. As such we have revised our 2013 and 2014 expectations. We have lowered our pretax profit and earnings per share expectations for 2013 by around 5%. The Aviation division, which is the main driver of the growth and increased rating of the group, continues to make progress and has good long term growth opportunities. However, we lower our sum of the parts based target price to 774p from 834p and lower our recommendation to hold from add.

Also heading lower was Balfour Beatty, which has fallen 10.5p to 273p after UBS cut from neutral to sell. UBS said:

We downgrade Balfour Beatty following a bounce back in the share price which we see as unwarranted given still difficult fundamentals. Our new price target of 245p is based on sum of the parts and attributes more value to the PPP [public-private partnership] portfolio, where asset values have exceeded our expectations. However, a higher pension deficit and deteriorating trends in professional services (particularly Australia) mean this upside is constrained. While we forecast a better 2014 as the underperforming UK construction business improves, a 15% downside to our valuation means we downgrade to sell.
